issue.title: Support outputting a STEP file with per-face colors
issue.body:
I need to set per-face colors on programmatically created shapes, then export into STEP format. Please help me find a way to do this. I'm somewhat familiar with the underlying C++ OCCT, and I'm more than happy to contribute code. I'm filing this issue so we can discuss and align on the best approach here.

Here's a self-contained demo of the approach I found so far:
https://github.com/mkovaxx/cadquery_fused_assembly/tree/4572a63616a614f3920c859b5224c8d4aaed3d64

I create each face as a separate shape, then pass it to the `Assembly.add` method along with its desired color. Saving the assembly as STEP then contains the colors as expected.

For details, see this section:
https://github.com/mkovaxx/cadquery_fused_assembly/blob/4572a63616a614f3920c859b5224c8d4aaed3d64/src/tubes.py#L22-L37

However, this approach has two severe limitations.

First, the output contains topologically disconnected shells. I expected this to be resolved by setting `ExportModes.FUSED` on the `Assembly.save` method, unfortunately that does not help.

Second, the output contains no volumes. There doesn't seem to be a way to get around this without extending CadQuery in some way.

issue.title: More robust initialization of the vtk window
Sweep or Thicken a non-planar surface along a vector
issue.body:
I have created a `parametricSurface` that I want to sweep/extrude in a particular direction (say the Z axis).
The closest I could come to doing this was to use the `thicken` function on a `Face` that I created from the surface. 
However, this sweeps the surface along the surface normal (not along a particular direction). 

I dug into the source to find that the `thicken` function uses BRepOffset_MakeOffset to do the thickening. 
How can I use either cadquery or BRep to perform this kind of a sweep?
Is there a modification to the `thicken` function source code that can enable this?

issue.title: Sweep a surface or Thicken a surface along a vector
issue.body:
I have created a `parametricSurface` that I want to sweep/extrude in a particular direction (say the Z axis).
The closest I could come to doing this was to use the `thicken` function on a `Face` that I created from the surface. 
However, this sweeps the surface along the surface normal (not along a particular direction). 

I dug into the source to find that the `thicken` function uses BRepOffset_MakeOffset to do the thickening. 
How can I use either cadquery or BRep to perform this kind of a sweep?
Is there a source modification to the `thicken` function source code that can enable this?

issue.title: Added argument handling for ASCII export of assemblies to GLTF and STL
issue.body: The `binary` option for `occ_impl.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF()` was not getting passed through from the `assembly.save()` call. This PR fixes that and also adds the `ascii` option for STL export as well.

comment.body:
@adam-urbanczyk, @jmwright Is there a policy against git sqaush?  If not, perhaps squash might be applied more on merge.
 
For example, I like black, but maybe squash commits such as black fixes, codecov tests, etc.:
```
$ git log | grep -i black | wc
     89     460    3151
```

issue.title: Set glTF export format automatically based on .gltf or .glb file extension
issue.body:
Blender example:

![blender_file_export_gltf](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/229012c9-7113-4c80-9207-6cc6598771ef)

Format is selected in the _Format_ drop-down list, for JSON:

![blender_gltf](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/75a06963-6b77-4841-b6ad-1b9a33d30ee6)

Note that the file extension is updated automatically based on the format selection.

Binary:

![blender_glb](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/50edb1d3-c486-4c45-a2d0-4dfcf28e2709)


FreeCAD example:
![freecad_gltf](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/e5d327cd-0542-4540-9988-f1a4c9420757)

Export format is determined based on the file extension.
```
$ file PartDesignExample-Body.*
PartDesignExample-Body.bin:  data
PartDesignExample-Body.glb:  glTF binary model, version 2, length 18528 bytes
PartDesignExample-Body.gltf: JSON text data
```

Current cadquery behavior:

The following results in a binary glTF (good - as expected).
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.glb")
```

This also results in a binary glTF (not expected).
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.gltf")
```

I'd propose to change `exportGLTF` to respect the convention of the file extension regarding output format.  The `binary` parameter can then apply only to the cases where the file extension is unknown.


Proposed change, this would export JSON text data glTF:
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.gltf")
```

Export binary glTF:
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.glb")
# or
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.customextension")
```

Export JSON text data glTF:
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.customextension", False)
```

issue.title: Set glTF export format automatically based on .gltf or .glb file extension
issue.body:
Blender example:

![blender_file_export_gltf](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/229012c9-7113-4c80-9207-6cc6598771ef)

Format is selected in the _Format_ drop-down list, for JSON:

![blender_gltf](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/75a06963-6b77-4841-b6ad-1b9a33d30ee6)

Note that the file extension is updated automatically based on the format selection.

Binary:

![blender_glb](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/50edb1d3-c486-4c45-a2d0-4dfcf28e2709)


FreeCAD example:
![freecad_gltf](https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery/assets/16394272/e5d327cd-0542-4540-9988-f1a4c9420757)

Export format is determined based on the file extension.
```
$ file PartDesignExample-Body.*
PartDesignExample-Body.bin:  data
PartDesignExample-Body.glb:  glTF binary model, version 2, length 18528 bytes
PartDesignExample-Body.gltf: JSON text data
```

Current cadquery behavior:

The following results in a binary glTF (good - as expected).
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.glb")
```

This also results in a binary glTF (not expected).
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.gltf")
```

I'd propose to change `exportGLTF` to respect the convention of the file extension regarding output format.  The `binary` parameter can then apply only to the cases where the file extension is unknown.


Proposed change, this would export JSON text data glTF:
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.gltf")
```

Export binary glTF:
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.glb")
# or
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.customextension")
```

Export JSON text data glTF:
```py
cq.exporters.assembly.exportGLTF(assy, "assy.customextension", False)
```

issue.title: Assembly save support .glb for binary glTF export
issue.body:
```py
assy.save("myassy.glb")
```

This currently fails with:
```
ValueError: Unknown extension, specify export type explicitly
```

See also #1419.  .glb is for binary glTF export. 

The request is to automatically recognize the .glb extension and save as binary glTF.

issue.title: Assembly save support .glb for binary glTF export
issue.body:
```py
assy.save("myassy.glb")
```

This currently fails with:
```
ValueError: Unknown extension, specify export type explicitly
```

See also #1419.  .glb is for binary glTF export. 

The request is to automatically recognize the .glb extension and save as binary glTF.

review.body: I think this looks good @adam-urbanczyk but it did not seem to fix the problem for users in the linked issue. However, I don't think this change will hurt anything, and could eliminate a possible race condition on initialization.

commits.message: Added argument handling for ASCII export of assemblies to GLTF and STL
Added GLTF export to the documentation
Improved testing method for binary files
Removed check for specific exception message because it varies between platforms
Made exportGLTF the focus of binary/ASCII file extension handling
Fixed glb extension not being recognized, and also glTF capitalization
Still trying to get CodeCov to see the covered case
Moved exportGLTF assert into separate test
Making a minor change to see if CodeCov will pick up the changes
Reverting change to try to trigger CodeCov
Added tests for both explicit and implicit binary exportGLTF argument

Merge pull request #1418 from CadQuery/ascii_exports

Added argument handling for ASCII export of assemblies to GLTF and STL
